identificationModule.briefTitle: Feasibility of the Adapted H-GRASP Feedback Program in the Chronic Phase Post Stroke.
identificationModule.officialTitle: The Feasibility of the Adapted H-GRASP Feedback Program for Perceived and Daily Life UL Activity in Patients With Good Observed But Low Perceived Activity in the Chronic Phase Post Stroke: a Pilot Study.

descriptionModule.briefSummary: In a recent cross-sectional study, it was shown that people with a good observed upper limb (UL) motor function but low perceived UL activity show a reduced daily-life UL activity. The investigators will now investigate the feasibility of a phone-monitored home exercise and feedback program for the UL following stroke and the preliminary effects on the perceived UL activity and actual daily-life UL activity for participants with good observed UL motor function but low perceived UL activity in the chronic phase post-stroke.

armGroups.label: AH-GRASP feedback intervention group
armGroups.description: All study participants will receive the AH-GRASP feedback intervention.

interventions.name: Adapted H-GRASP feedback program
interventions.description: Combination of the Home-Graded Repetitive Arm Supplementary Program with in home accelerometer-based feedback

primaryOutcomes.description: % of individuals who were eligible and agreed to participate
% of participants who completed the intervention
% of participants who achieved 12 hours of average weekly exercise
# of participants with increased pain while performing exercises as measured by visual analogue scale
Contribution to the activity of one upper limb (UL) versus the other: hours of activity of the affected divided by the unaffected UL
Contribution to the activity of one upper limb (UL) versus the other: hours of activity of the affected divided by the unaffected UL
Contribution to the activity of one upper limb (UL) versus the other: hours of activity of the affected divided by the unaffected UL

primaryOutcomes.measure: Hand subscale of the Stroke Impact Scale version 3.0 (SIS-Hand)
primaryOutcomes.description: Perceived activity of the affected UL. Minimum 0 - maximum 100; higher scores mean better outcome.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Hand subscale of the Stroke Impact Scale version 3.0 (SIS-Hand)
primaryOutcomes.description: Perceived activity of the affected UL. Minimum 0 - maximum 100; higher scores mean better outcome.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Hand subscale of the Stroke Impact Scale version 3.0 (SIS-Hand)
primaryOutcomes.description: Perceived activity of the affected UL. Minimum 0 - maximum 100; higher scores mean better outcome.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Observed motor function of the affected UL (shoulder, arm, wrist, hand, and fingers)
Grasp, grip, pinch and gross movement of the affected UL

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Motor Activity Log - 14 Item Version Amount Of Use (MAL-14 AOU)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Patient-reported amount of UL use in daily life

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Motor Activity Log - 14 Item Version Quality Of Movement (MAL-14 QOM)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Patient-reported quality of UL use in daily life
Global disability. Minimum 0 - maximum 5; higher scores mean worse outcome.
Symptoms of anxiety and depression. Minimum 0 - maximum 42; higher scores mean worse outcome.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Confidence in Arm and Hand Movement Scale (CAHM)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Perceived self-efficacy in performing tasks with the affected UL. Minimum 0 - maximum 100; higher scores mean better outcome.
Pain intensity in the affected UL from 0 (no pain) to 10 (extreme). Minimum 0, maximum 10, higher scores mean worse outcome.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: EuroQol Five Dimensions Five Levels Questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Health-related quality of life. Minimum 0, maximum 100, higher scores mean better outcome.
Sum of all seconds recorded when the activity count was nonzero and converted to hours
Intensity of the movement: sum of the vector magnitude from the two ULs

Contribution to the activity of one limb versus the other: natural log of the vector magnitude of the affected UL divided by the vector magnitude of the unaffected UL, whereby values greater than and less than -7 were replaced by 7 and -7, respectively, to categorize single limb movement.
Graphical representation of accelerometry data from both ULs

otherOutcomes.measure: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS)
otherOutcomes.description: Neurological impairments. Minimum 0, maximum 42, higher scores mean worse outcome.
Performance in activities of daily living

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Voluntary written informed consent of the participant has been obtained prior to any screening procedures
2. First-ever unilateral, supratentorial stroke, as defined by the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association
3. Minimum six months after stroke
4. Living in the community
5. ≥18 years old
6. Good observed UL motor function but low perceived UL activity. Good observed UL motor function is defined as a score \>50/66 on the Fugl-Meyer Assessment-Upper Extremity (FMA-UE). Low perceived UL activity is defined as a score ≤75/100 on the hand subscale of the Stroke Impact Scale version 3.0 (SIS-Hand).

Exclusion Criteria:

1. Other neurological condition than stroke
2. Musculoskeletal disorder that affects UL use
3. No informed consent
4. Participation in an interventional Study with an investigational medicinal product (IMP) or device
